title: Care worker describes 'impossible conditions' which forced her out of job
text:

She’s dedicated her life to looking after elderly and vulnerable people, but as Nicola Frape explains, care work nearly destroyed her.

The 36-year-old spent years as a domiciliary worker, travelling to people’s homes to administer medication and personal care.

But long hours, not being paid for travel and never knowing what her monthly wage would be eventually forced her to quit. Nicola, who juggles work with looking after her daughter at their home in Ashford in Kent is a victim of the UK’s growing gig economy – and she isn’t alone.

As she says: “I had to get out. I loved the people, loved caring, but there was never enough time. I didn’t get paid for travel – or the extra time I spent with them because they are so lonely. I’d get home two hours late and was always worried about money.”

Next month a new Ken Loach film, Sorry We Missed You, tells the story of people like Nicola. It follows the lives of a care worker and a courier driver, highlighting the damaging effects of these ‘non-jobs’, where zero hours and precarious agency contracts are now the norm.

Fellow care worker, Stevie Hookway, 30, from Barking in Essex, says she is depressed and in debt because of her job.

“You never know how much you’re getting paid. I’ve had to choose which three bills to pay this month,” she says.

“You only get paid for the time you spend in a client’s house – not the hour it takes to get there on public transport. I’m in rent arrears already and on top of work pressure, worrying about money is making me depressed.”

Sadly Nicola and Stevie’s stories are not unusual – with many British workers being forced to join this insecure gig economy.

A staggering 4.7 million Brits, almost one in ten working-age adults are now working via a freelance platform. That’s double the number from 2016, and 80 per cent are women.

The GMB union, one of those that represents British care workers, said its members were ‘undervalued and underpaid’.

And a recent cross-party report into social care warns of a ‘workforce crisis’. When you hear what has happened to dedicated, compassionate staff like Nicola it’s impossible to disagree.

New film exposes grim work reality

From the team that brought you I, Daniel Blake comes Sorry We Missed You, a powerful exploration of the contemporary world of work.

In the fim, released in cinemas November 1, overworked contract nurse Abbie (Debbie Honeywood) cares for disabled and elderly people, often at the expense of tucking in her own children at night.

This raw tale shines a light on the injustice suffered by thousands of workers facing similar conditions, in the hope of change.
description: Poor pay and long shifts were too much for Nicola in an industry which features in new Ken Loach film 'Sorry We Missed You'
